ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Not a ton - there literally wasn't a single "application" topic covered all year. The course mainly consisted of limited problem solving and some theory which would fit better in 225.

Matrix operations, elimination, fundamental subspaces (column/null), bases, determinants, projection, orthogonality (e.g. Gram-Schmidt), eigenvalues and eigenvectors, diagonalization and simple differential equations, singular value decomposition.

Occasionally techniques were presented alongside real life applications (e.g. image compression).
Linear algebra.
I learned how to analyze linear systems.
linear algebra concepts and practical applications of those concepts to OLS and image compression for example
Learned about vectors, matrices, and how to manipulate them to solve linear questions.
Not much
I developed a large knowledge of matrices

Useful variety of topics in linear algebra. Learned some proofs but this course was not at all proof heavy. Covers a lot more linear algebra than math 230. Gives a lot of real life applications like modeling systems and data compression.

I learned the basics of 2D vectors up through concepts like singular value decomposition and its applications for image compression. We learned many important linear algebra theorems (like the rank-nullity theorem and spectral theorem), and fundamental algorithmic methods of solving linear equations (gaussian elimination, gram-schmidt, diagonalization, etc). The definitions/notation/terms used throughout this course appeard to not follow what many others use (i.e. using the term nullspace instead of kernal) based on my browsing in stackexchange for help with lecture concepts, but that probably isn't an issue, especially if you go into more pure math later. Some of the concepts I learned like matrix inversion and linear transformations were ones that I wish I had learned sooner - some s&ds courses I took before would have been a lot less painful having already known these topics!

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I truly do not understand how Yale as an institution tolerates such poor classes in our math department. The current state of 222 (abysmally taught, horribly organized, and unfairly graded) is frankly an embarrassment to the school. This has probably been the worst course I have taken in my life. I ended up switching it credit/d because I had 0 clue where I stood grade-wise relative to the rest of the class. Stay away if you can.

I think it's an effective way to learn these topics. The course mainly teaches computational methods, so I will say it could be a little boring at times (since many problems would be similar or mostly following a rote technique), but I appreciated that the problem set makers including some more interesting conceptual problems as well. 

I'm wondering if the course could incorporate more programming, since there's not much reason to do these methods by hand anymore except to learn them. One question on the bonus problem set involved image compression - maybe there could be more questions like that?

The teaching of the concepts could be improved immensely. I found myself learning from Khan Academy more than anything else. I found the teaching disorganized, and the lectures need to be better at explaining the significance of what we even are learning instead of just giving us the method and some vague theoretical proof. 

I think class could be improved by organizing it such that: 
1.) Tell us what the thing we're learning is (i.e. Eigenvalues)
2.) Tell us the method with some examples. 
3.) Give the big picture (i.e. what's the significance of an eigenvalue?)

Having it taught by all three professors made the learning more equitable for all students, but I found that I understood my assigned professor the best so I wish he had been my only professor the whole semester.

Strengths:
- reasonable exams
- incorporates practical applications of course concepts
- responsive instructors

Weaknesses:
- not the most engaging lectures
- prerecorded lectures were a bit on the long end during some weeks

Strength: The live "class" twice a week was where I did most of my learning. The discussion sections were also super helpful to do more examples and ask more nuanced questions.

Weakness: The recorded lectures were not my style. A one hour lecture would take more twice the amount of time.
The strengths are that the teacher was very clear on the material that he was teaching. The weakness was that it was online, so taking a lot of notes was difficult

The manner in which the material was taught was rather difficult to understand. Despite watching all classes, material was seldom understood due to the overload of terminology seemingly out of nowhere.

Sometimes some wrong information was given in lecture or notes or answers or something and that made some things really confusing. Notes and slides were given and were useful but I think it would be more useful if they were all typed instead of hand written and if they included the important comments that were spoken in lecture but weren't bullet pointed or mentioned in the notes.

A strength was the variety of practice problems that were given to us, either in lectures or in the optional sections. The professor was pretty good about explaining his steps, and answered questions really well. A con was that in this this semester, 3 different professors took turns recording a given week's asynchronous lecture videos for all of the math 222 students across sections. While Prof Landa's lectures were always pretty good, the other professors' were not. It was harder to get a good flow of learning because of this. Also, the psets became increasingly difficult, and would have personally been near impossible to complete without the help of a study group. This was combatted by another major strength - the quality of peer tutors was astounding - they were friendly, funny, and helpful. They really made the class worthwhile

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Office hours occasionally helped, but when I sought an explanation of a concept outside of how lecture videos taught, I was referred back to the same lecture videos I did not understand.

Recorded lectures were good, allowed us to watch and rewatch whenever we needed. Class time was also useful for practicing problems and asking questions. These pandemic practices were generally very good.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: No chance. Take 225 if you can bear it, or wait until 222 is taught by a better professor.

I'd recommend it if you want to learn about matrices and linear algebra for other applications, without worrying about proofs or purer math. You won't learn many direct applications in this class (although you might be exposed to fields in which these methods are used). If you want to learn the math concepts more deeply, 225 would probably be a better bet.
Most definitely not. You're better off learning linear algebra off from Khan Academy. Though if anyone is taking this class, it's definitely for a requirement so...

Yes! This is a challenging course, but I can say that I see a lot of practical use for course material. Far better than Math 120/Math 115. Would recommend this course to those looking to take a math course beyond Math 120
Yes, linear algebra is super interesting. The psets can be time consuming, and the exams can be rough, but I liked the class.
Better lectures

Great course to take if you're just interested in learning topics and applications of linear algebra and learning how to run calculations and solve systems of equations. Take one of the proof based versions if you're interested in that. This course is just learning how to do the calculations for various applications

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Recorded lecture and virtual sections
New material was presented via pre-recorded lectures, while the instructors held live review/problem solving sessions during the nominal class period.
Sometimes I went to the live class lecture
prerecorded lectures

The class was a combination of prerecorded lectures and then live class where the professor went over the same content with varying examples. The recorded lectures weren't my favorite, but the live virtual lecture twice a week was a great space to implement what we learned in application.
live, discussion sections twice a week
Recorded lectures that we had to watch before class + live virtual lecture where we could ask questions and recap the material from the recorded lectures and solve practice problems
Weekly recorded lectures, and a live zoom class where lecture concepts were briefly reviewed and students did practice problems in groups.
Asynchronous lectures with synchronous problem-solving sessions during scheduled class times
